title: Arpita Saggar
text:
Hello!
I am a PhD student within the UKRI CDT in AI for Medical Diagnosis and Care at the University of Leeds. My doctoral research focuses on using generative AI to create patient simulations for medical training. I am fortunate to be supervised by Professor David Hogg, Dr Duygu Sarikaya, Dr Jonathan Darling and Professor Vania Dimitrova.
Before starting my PhD, I was a Data Science for Social Good fellow at the University of Warwick, where I worked with Save The Children UK and UNICEF to map child poverty across sub-Saharan Africa. My background is in Computing, and Iâ€™ve previously worked on research projects at the intersection of AI and healthcare.





News



[Dec 2025] I delivered a guest lecture on Responsible Personalisation Illustrated with LLMs for the COMP3771 module at UoL


[Nov 2025] I was selected as a DAAD AInet Fellow (11/2025 Cohort)


[Oct 2025] I attended ECAI 2025 in Bologna and presented Score Before You Speak


[Sep 2025] I presented my poster on persona-conditioned dialogue generation at the UK AI Research Symposium in Newcastle


[Aug 2025] I presented my research on ChatGPT-simulated clinical training scenarios at the AMEE Conference in Barcelona


[Jul 2025] Score Before You Speak has been accepted to the European Conference on Artificial Intelligence (ECAI)


[Jun 2025] I shared the Best Poster Prize with Yushi Guo at the Annual Conference of the AI-Medical CDT


[May 2025] I won Peopleâ€™s Choice Prize at the London Hopper Colloquium, organised by UCL Computer Science, EPSRC, BCS Academy of Computing and GSA Capital


[May 2025] I presented my research on ChatGPT-simulated clinical training scenarios at the Research Presentation Day organised by the British Federation of Women Graduates


[Mar 2025] My team won first place in the Easy Read Image Generation Hackathon organised by Leeds Digital Health

title: About
text: My research interests span generative AI, human-computer interaction, and AI-enhanced learning. Iâ€™m interested in investigating methods to improve the realism of foundation models, and combining these models across different modalities to produce interactive simulacra of human behaviour. My doctoral research falls within the AI Research Theme and Iâ€™m part of the MIRAI (Medical Imaging and GeneRative AI) and AI4L (AI for Languages) Research Groups at the University of Leeds.
